Off Topic I know.. but....
Best code Riot has ever written, well except you forgot to add comments. C+
Code should be self documenting. If it needs comments, you didn't write clean code. That is my official stance.

My official stance is as follows:

"As long as I don't have to maintain / debug / review / work with / look in its general direction, everyone can code as he pleases. As soon as I have to get involved in any way, things are either commented and maintain Linux Kernel Indention standards, or my only involvement will be a sardonic grin while slowly sipping coffee from my Darth Vader mug."

:-)

There can be exceptions.

While the majority of code can be self-documenting, basic descriptions may be useful in certain situations.

I've needed to insert comments when using an algorithm (i.e. Haversine formula) or extending the functionality of an existing Java class (i.e. Extending Java's SimpleDateFormat class to strictly validate dates).

If I'm using haversine directly, I'm probably writing for a microcontroller .. that's a different game. Code gets ugly there, so yeah .. documentation.

Ideally your memory footprint isn't a constraint and moving those types of operations to a calculator or library is optimal. In that case, the logic is entirely self contained and the class/file names are annotating the usage.

Entending SImpleDateFormat? Let's just all agree to use milliseconds.

> If I'm using haversine directly, I'm probably writing for a microcontroller .. that's a different game.

I was just using it to sort locations by their distance from the user (since I had their latitude and longitude).

It wasn't necessarily complex, but the clarification would be useful for anyone else who needed the same functionality.

> Entending SImpleDateFormat? Let's just all agree to use milliseconds.

Sadly, we have to work within the constraints we are given.

I wanted February 40th to be considered invalid rather than parsed as March 12th and my options were limited.

Annoyingly, SimpleDateFormat's "strict" parsing isn't actually strict.

> Code should be self documenting.

Do you use Doxygen then?
I have never seen comments written for such simple if statements, I would have taken points off if a comment was actually included.
Have to find a reason to not give riot an A.

Hey this might be a liiiiittle bit off topic, but is there any chance a player gets their punishment lowered when they show signs of reforming? I mean if you have been punished twice can the account still go back to the state of a new account? Or does he keep the punishment tier forever? If no can you tell me some raw values on how long it takes to get back to the reformed/clean state?
Yes, accounts return back to 'good' state after showing sufficient 'not bad' behavior.

Hope you're still around. I'd like to know if the average time to decay one punishment tier is different per tier, as in, does it take longer to go from just being 14 day banned down to the 25 chat than it does to go from a 10 game chat restriction down to a clean status?
More severe behavior and behavior histories take longer to get to a clean slate than a less egregious/persistent behavior.
"Clean slate" keeps being used. Am I to take that as you can't drop individual tiers, you can but you just haven't said yet, or "clean slate" doesn't mean what I think it does?

You can drop tiers, and you can get your account into the same state as an account that has never been punished. When I say 'clean slate', I mean the account is the same as any other player that has never been penalized, or a new account.

Tyvm for the help! Sorry if I pester you with nearly identical questions; if the wording was open to interpretation it'd be hard to use as a source when helping other players :D

If you're ever interested in reaching out to us through Discord, hit us up in the [Moderation Discord!](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/ZfE311GQ-discord-verification)
